TopicTitle: Which of your craft has the most part?

Articles.Content:
I don't think I need to explain a lot:tell what's your craft is designed to do and how many part it has!

Mine is a rocket of 191 parts, designed to bring two kerbal on Duna(and a third one in orbit) and bring them back,due to the fact I forgot to put dome parts(the mechjeb module on the lander(first attempt) and the chutes(second attempt).

While writing this, I am still doing the third(and hopefully the last) attempt to achieve the mission.

Edited November 4, 2013 by goldenpeach

*Waits for Whackjob*

I got 715 for PTV:Oddessy

Edited November 4, 2013 by Spartwo
I had a pure srb one with more than 500 srb's iirc

My largest vessel currently in use is my station orbiting Kerbin at 377 parts.

As to single rocket? Maybe 250-260. Usually by the time I start hitting 200 parts I decide to make it modular and build it in orbit. I did have a ship in .20 that was intended to visit every planet/moon in one trip and drop probes off at all the planets that came in just under 800 parts, but again built in orbit.
I dont remember well but it was my DOS-Valent S1 equipped whit complete Eve subsystem range or Grand Tour:Eve, it had 160 - 240 parts, 70% of them were only the payload.

The station I'm building in orbit is around 650 and less than half built.

ETA:

Edited November 4, 2013 by phunk

For a single craft, 400-something for my crazy cyclogyro (I know, it's not a rocket):

I also built a 500-plus part space station before.

I just changed the thread to include planes.

For those wondering, my mission is going well so far!

EDIT: I have been able to return my Kerbal from Duna,the mission is a success! \o/

Edited November 4, 2013 by goldenpeach

Depends on purpose.

For my playing in sandbox (trading file with a friend), where we're at war, I've built a Kessler Bomb with 698 parts.

For my use in trying to complete the Career mode, I've gotten up to at most 192 parts for a spaceplane capable of deploying 3 science probes.

Y'all don't mind watching slideshows? I built a grand-tour mothership that all told was around 500 parts, but it just wasn't worth it. Stripped it down and hacked myself some custom parts to get it down to under 300 including the eve lander iirc.

Y'all don't mind watching slideshows? I built a grand-tour mothership that all told was around 500 parts, but it just wasn't worth it. Stripped it down and hacked myself some custom parts to get it down to under 300 including the eve lander iirc.

I still get playable frame rates flying up the Kessler Bombs. That being said, what I use for a desktop is not exactly consumer grade, and I run KSP at reduced resolution and quality settings. My friend, on the other hand, was mad cause I left 400 parts in orbit with my one launched weapon.

Someone go get a hold of Whackjob! He will have a fun time with this thread!

And my largest has been around 600-700 parts.

I still get playable frame rates flying up the Kessler Bombs. That being said, what I use for a desktop is not exactly consumer grade, and I run KSP at reduced resolution and quality settings. My friend, on the other hand, was mad cause I left 400 parts in orbit with my one launched weapon.

Mine's not either, but I don't turn settings down.

Someone needs to photoshop up a "Summon Whackjob" trap card.

3,400-ish parts on the pad.

... but, this one was larger.

I think it was about 4,300 parts.

I'm working on the space shuttle that is about 450 parts! It does not lag at all....

Well, if I turn on the landing lights the fps decreases to around 3... It's actually kind of funny if you toggle them on and off. Slow... Fast! Slow... Fast! Slow... Fast!

Edited November 4, 2013 by RocketPilot573
345 for Dunebeam, currently my only 3-man duna-landing-and-return vehicle. It's also quite overbuilt. I could probably strip quite a few fuel tanks off it...

Whackjob, this thread lagged as I got to your pictures. 4300 parts! that's...it's...I...., what the heck to you run that on, some kinda secret military grade, nuclear powered, cryogenic cooled monster that is otherwise used to count the number of atoms in the universe or something? Seriously my computer is pretty cool, but right now its having hysterics in the corner at the thought of running either of those. I don't think that my entire space program (even my 22yo one) totalled that many parts!
I've got a laptop with a 2.53 Ghz quad core processor. That's all.

I've got a laptop with a 2.53 Ghz quad core processor. That's all.

What! You run that on a laptop!? You must have incredible patience! Respect!

I've got a laptop with a 2.53 Ghz quad core processor. That's all.

*Faints* A LAPTOP!!!!!??? You... you... how... why... what...*Dies*

That must be one epic laptop...

Whackjob, you have more patience than I do. Four of my Kessler bombs can bring my system to its knees, screaming and crying the whole way, and you've got way less CPU horsepower than I do. Two GTX 580's on a dual-CPU workstation board packing a pair of 6 core Xeons keeps my head out of trouble, but I've learned how to make things that can bring it down.

Currently testing how many parts I can put on something and still make it fly...

What! You run that on a laptop!? You must have incredible patience! Respect!

Longest launch into orbit took me two hours and twenty minutes in real time.
Hey there, just a reminder to everyone to stay on topic, which is "How much parts does your biggest ship have", not "can you turn me into a Pokemon card"
